messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:38): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: I can't believe I saw that on WHATWG IRC!
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:41): In unrelated news, today's xkcd is cool
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:47): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Where can I get info about the html test harness?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:48): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Info of waht sort?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:48): Sufficient information to write a test using it.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:48): Hmm, the documentation is not great
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (21:49): I can fix that now I guess
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (21:49): That'd be cool.  Pilgrim is asking me about it, and apparently doesn't want to start irc on his mac.
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:07): IE9 will be shipping with the HTML5 parser, right? While I'm asking, have either Safari or Chrome shipped the parser yet?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:19): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: IE9 parser is not conformant
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:19): unfortunately
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:20): and the WebKit HTML5 parser has not shipped in normal Safari or Chrome yet, afaik
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:20): I think it's in the current Chrome betas though
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:20): or I would sure think it would be by now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (22:21): Chrome 7 beta
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:21): I *think* it is, but I'd have to ask to make sure.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:21): Or you can hand me a testcase that'll only pass in an HTML5-compliant parser, and I'll check what I have.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:41): Saw the discussion on www-archive re libxml2...
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:41): I think the key is to get libxml2 to pass the same tests as Henri's parser does
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:41): oh, if the libxml2 guys want to impl the html5 parsing algorithm, i'm all for it
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:41): that would be awesome
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:42): that's the key IF.  Any evidence that that is the case?
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:43): I have no evidence either way
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:44): this thread came out of the nodejs list, on which I was advocating using Aria's JS impl of the HTML5 parser and not the libxml2 HTML parser
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:48): My guess is that Aria is more compliant but libxml2 is much faster.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:48): quick scan, and I see a thread from 2008 about libxml2 implementing html5 that seems to have died...
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:50): *nod*. for my needs, correct trumps fast as I'm using the parser in the publication workflow of what ends up being a pile of static assets served by apache
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (22:50): scales nicely :)
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:51): libxml2 is used widely; I once tried to help maintain a Ruby port of the html5 library, but have slipped back to using libxml2.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:51): speed wasn't the issue for me... support was.
9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:00): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: is there a C port though? that would make it easy to wrap in whatever language and keep decent speed

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (23:01): hsivonen's has code that converts his java parser into C and then includes that into firefox; the problem is that that code presumes that you have mozilla's runtime library
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (23:02): I think the right thing to do is to pelt the libxml2 guys with bug reports :-P
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (23:02): Anybody remember where the test suite is for html5lib?  (I used to know...)
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (23:03): hg clone https://html5lib.googlecode.com/hg/ html5lib
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (23:03): then it's html5lib/testdata
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (23:03): oh, I thought it was a separate project...
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (23:03): oh, could be. I've been pulling it out of html5lib for the elisp tokenizer
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:04): I would doubt that the libxml2 HTML parser would ever pass the html5lib tests without pretty much being rewritten
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:07): It isn't a seperate project
d5f549c13db7f29a9f9c330876295a67 (23:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: posted my comments on PUT/DELETE into bugzilla. hopefully they make sense/are helpful. i'll be avail for follow up. thanks.
